items.body_markdown:
To avoid having to save an API ClientId in the code (and in a public code repo on Github), I want to pass it as a parameter when building the project using MSBuild (with Jenkins and ClickOnce).

The [parameter][1] I set in the Jenkins config:
`/p:O365ApiClientId="abcde"`

However, I wasn't able to find a way to access the parameter from within my C#-code. What I tried:

 *  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36669419/how-to-get-value-of-msbuild-variable

Not sure if I am missing something...

  [1]: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms164311.aspx

Additionally, I would like the drop down menu's to be populated to a mode. I have spent a decent amount of time trying to get this to work and have made very little progress...

Any help would be great!

</head>

items.title: TButton on firemonkey form not showing on android
items.body:
I have a regular TButton on a firemonkey form. In the form's FormShow event I adjust the button width with the following line of code:

Button1->Width = Form1->ClientWidth * 0.8;

The button shows up fine on iOS and is sized properly. On Android the button just doesn't show up. I changed my code to the following and it works fine on Android (and iOS).

Button1->Width = Screen->Width * 0.8;

I'd like to understand why the first line of code doesn't work on Android. Note, if i use either line of code in the form's FormPaint event it works fine. Obviously this isn't urgent - i'd just like to know why the first line of code fails in FormShow.

items.title: Questions regarding espresso
items.body:
I've got a few question regarding espresso. Please help me out, I am struggling with espresso immensely. All tutorial I've found are extremely simplified, or are using methods that are already deprecated. If anyone have a more comprehensive tutorial on how to use espresso, especially in regards to how to deal with Fragments, please let me know. Thank you!

  1. All the tutorial I've seen gave a very simple example for an app that only uses Activity and not Fragments. What happen if I have a fragment inside my activity, and all my views are within the fragment? How do I write out the @test?

My solution: 

activityTestRule.getActivity().getSupportFragmentManager().beginTransaction();

"then proceed with rest of the test" is this correct? because it doesn't seem to be working for me.

  1. What if you want to start testing from the 2nd activity, and the 2nd activity requires some intent Extras from the 1st activity to function properly?

my solution: 

Context targetContext = InstrumentationRegistry.getInstrumentation().getTargetContext();
Intent intent = new Intent(targetContext, 2ndActivity.class);
        intent.putExtra(Key, Value);
activityTestRule.launchActivity(intent);

(I can simulate what ever Key,Value pair I want by manually inputting it here. Is this correct?)

  1. In my Fragment, I have multiple asynchronous tasks. So I use CountingIdlingResource to track the idlingResource. How do I pass this idlingResource to my Test? All online example have idlingResource inside an Activity, since no example ever shows how to deal with fragments. I need to pass it to the test so I can register it.

  2. Talk about registration, is this the correct way to register it?

    IdlingRegistry.getInstance().register(idlingResource);

All solutions I've found uses 

Espresso.unregisterIdlingResources(mIdlingResource);

But this is already deprecated

items.title: How to upload multiple files in angular js and convert it into base 64
items.body:
I am used single file upload and convert it to base 64 which was working fine.I am trying to upload multiple files and convert each file to base 64 in which i have used the following directive.What happens is all the image is converted into a single base 64 I would like to convert each image file to base 64.so that can anyone help me how to achieve it.

Directive:

"use strict";
(function() {
angular.module("SS.pages").directive("fileModel", fileModel);

/** @ngInject */
function fileModel($parse, $q) {
 return {
  restrict: "A",
  link: function(scope, element, attrs) {
    var model = $parse(attrs.fileModel),
      modelSetter = model.assign;
    element.bind("change", function() {
      var files = [];
      angular.forEach(element[0].files,function(file) {
        files.push(file);
      });
      scope.$apply(function() {
        // var file = element[0].files[0];
        angular.forEach(files, function(file) {
          getFileBuffer(file).then(function(resp) {
            modelSetter(scope, resp);
          });
        });
      });
    });
  }
};
function getFileBuffer(file) {
  var deferred = new $q.defer();
  var reader = new FileReader();
  reader.onloadend = function(e) {
    deferred.resolve(e.target.result);
  };
  reader.onerror = function(e) {
    deferred.reject(e.target.error);
  };
  reader.readAsDataURL(file);
  return deferred.promise;
}
}

})();

Html:

<div class="form-group">
      <label translate>.NEW.UPLOAD</label>
      <input type="file" class="form-control" name="schemeupload" accept="image/jpeg,application/jpeg" file-model="vm.schemeApply.document" multiple/>
      <p class="help-block" translate>.NEW.UPLOADMESSAGE</p>
      <span class="help-block error-block basic-block" translate>.NEW.REQUIRED</span>
    </div>

items.body_markdown:
I'm writing UI automation for a web application which runs on iOS and Android. These tests run on remote Phone devices. So far, the tests with the same URLs run successfully for Android but they fail on iOS devices. 

**Root Cause:** 
I have a test suite where each test in the suite has to pass the authentication workflow and navigate to the Page Under Test. When I run the test on iPhone Safari, the first test executes fine. When the second test is started, the initial test URL directly lands on the home page (skipping the authentication part and driver still searches for Username, password fields) because the cookies are already stored on the browser.
 
Using `driver.manage.deleteAllCookies()` doesn't help.
 
Is there any way I can delete the cookies stored in Safari browser with automation?
 
P.S: The test suite works absolutely fine for Android platform.

**Technical Details:**

1. Test Framework - Selenium

2. Mobile Automation Framework - Appium

3. Device: iPhone - version 11 (internal tools setup on the cloud for test suite execution)

4. Browser: Safari
items.title: Delete Cookies on Mobile Safari using Selenium
items.body:
I'm writing UI automation for a web application which runs on iOS and Android. These tests run on remote Phone devices. So far, the tests with the same URLs run successfully for Android but they fail on iOS devices.

Root Cause: I have a test suite where each test in the suite has to pass the authentication workflow and navigate to the Page Under Test. When I run the test on iPhone Safari, the first test executes fine. When the second test is started, the initial test URL directly lands on the home page (skipping the authentication part and driver still searches for Username, password fields) because the cookies are already stored on the browser.

Using driver.manage.deleteAllCookies() doesn't help.

Is there any way I can delete the cookies stored in Safari browser with automation?

P.S: The test suite works absolutely fine for Android platform.

Technical Details:

  1. Test Framework - Selenium

  2. Mobile Automation Framework - Appium

  3. Device: iPhone - version 11 (internal tools setup on the cloud for test suite execution)

  4. Browser: Safari

items.title: How can I prevent "Bad request" when calling Firebase's `.onCall()` method?
items.body:
I've just upgraded to using Firebase Cloud Functions v1.x. According to this answer

Callable functions are exactly the same as HTTP functions

With that in mind, I've tried to convert my pre-1.x mock-code:

export const myHttpAction = functions.https.onRequest((req, res) => {
  try {
    const result = await myHttpActionWorker(req.body);
    return res.send({ status: 'OK' });
  } catch (err) {
    console.error(err);
    return res.status(500).send({ status: 'Server error' });
  }
});

to the following:

export const myHttpAction = functions.https.onCall(async (data, context) => {
  console.log(context.auth);
  try {
    const result = await myHttpActionWorker(data);
    return { status: 'OK' };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error(err);
    return { status: 'Server error' };
  }
});

But upon submission to my endpoint, /myHttpAction, with the same data that I used in pre-1.x, I get the following back:

{
  "error": {
    "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT",
    "message": "Bad Request"
  }
}

I'm not sure why the request is "bad" since it's exactly the same and Callable functions are "exactly the same". Any idea what gives?

My package.json specifies "firebase-functions": "^1.0.1".

items.title: How to call out @media in Additional CSS?
items.body:
Alright, so, I'm hoping this is an easy question, but I can't for the life of me get it working.

The situation:

  1. I've made some changes in the Additional CSS portion of the customize feature on my Wordpress theme.
  2. I've taught myself a few things, and I was able to edit the margins and whatnot of the footer widgets.
  3. They look great on desktop, not so much on mobile.

From research, I've found that you can call out @media criteria, theoretically making two sets of margin settings: one for a max screen size you set for mobile, and one for desktop.

Here's what I've been able to come up with:

#text-5 .widget-title{
    margin:0px 0px 10px 0px}
#text-6 .widget-title{
    margin:0px 0px 10px 0px}
#text-7 .widget-title{
    margin:0px 0px 10px 0px}
#custom_html-2 .widget-title{
    margin:0px 0px 10px 0px}
#text-7 .footer-row-2-widget.widget.widget_text{
    width: 100px;}
#text-7 {
    width: 200px;
    margin:-10px 0px 5px -10px}
#text-5 {
    width: 200px;
    margin:-10px 0px 5px 0px}
#text-6 {
    width: 300px;
    margin:-10px 0px 5px -50px}
#custom_html-2 {
    width: 350px;
    margin:-10px 0px 5px -50px}

This seems to be working so far. (I know negative pixels is not ideal, but I can't figure out how to otherwise move the columns to where I want them.)

So, how do I call out @media in the Additional CSS? Nothing I'm finding is helping to show what needs to be done for the Additional CSS box itself, but rather for the editor files, which I don't want to touch (aka break).

Thank you!

The site in question: http://q6q.118.myftpupload.com/

items.title: async/await - try ... catch inside $.when
items.body:
I'm working on a small project at work which requires multiple AJAX calls to various API endpoints. The first three require data from one another successively, and the last three can be ran independently as they do not have any relationship to the first three.

This is my first major foray into async/await, and actually utilizing promises for their intended purpose, and I've come to a point of confusion as to how to handle any exceptions. We're using Vue.js as our front-end framework and consuming JSON responses.

I call the functions containing my requests with this function:

fetchAllData: async function() {
    await this.getList()
    await this.getSecondListRelatedToFirst()
    await this.getThirdListRelatedToFirstAndSecond()
    this.getDateRange()
    getConversions()
    getVolumes()
}

The how the requests are running right now:

this.getList()
|------------> this.getSecondListRelatedToFirst()
              |----------> this.getThirdListRelatedToFirstAndSecond()
              |------> this.getDateRange()
              |------> getConversions()
              |------> getVolumes()

this.getList() runs, then this.getSecondListRelatedToFirst() runs when this.getList() resolves, and the last four run when this.getSecondListRelatedToFirst() resolves.

The requests are all structured fairly similar to this:

getList: function () {
    return $.ajax({
        type: "GET",
        url: '/api/endpoint',
        dataType: 'json',
        data: {
            param_one  : param_one,
            param_two  : param_two,
            param_three: param_three,
            ...
        }
    })
    .then(function(data, status, xhr) {
         let temp = _.map(data, function (d) {
             return {
                 // map some data here         
             }
         }.bind(this));

    }, function(jqXhr, textStatus, errorThrown) {
                console.error(errorThrown);
    })
    .catch(function(error){
         console.log.bind(error)
})

The basic idea is once the response comes back from the server, I manipulate the data into something more easily consumable by Vue, and move along with rendering the page.

Coming full circle, to the first function, fetchAllData, which is called in the mounted lifecycle property like so:

$.when( this.fetchAllData() )
 .then( function() {
    // do some other stuff
 })
 .fail(
      console.log.bind(console);
 );

And this is where my question lies. Considering I'm doing error catching at the AJAX level (with the then, catch blocks), do I need to do error catching here as well? And if so, how would I achieve that in the $.when block? Or is the final fail statement sufficient at this point in execution?

This question is probably a case of reading way too many use cases and not enough experience with Vue.js and async/await, I just need some clarification on best practices for this type of scenario. Thanks for any guidance!

items.body_markdown:
My goal would be to have docker container that connects to an OpenVPN server, and all traffic is routed through it from my computer.

This is how far I got:

1. I started an ubuntu container with macvlan network interface so it has an ip on my local network
2. Then on my computer I set the default gateway to the ip of the container. This works fine so far, I have internet access on my computer and it's routed through the container.
3. I connect the container to the OpenVPN server
4. The container has internet access, my computer doesn't
5. I can ping my computer from the container and I can ping the container from my computer, but there is no internet on my computer.

What am I missing? Can someone help please?
items.title: How can I route all traffic through a docker container connected to OpenVPN server
items.body:
My goal would be to have docker container that connects to an OpenVPN server, and all traffic is routed through it from my computer.

This is how far I got:

  1. I started an ubuntu container with macvlan network interface so it has an ip on my local network
  2. Then on my computer I set the default gateway to the ip of the container. This works fine so far, I have internet access on my computer and it's routed through the container.
  3. I connect the container to the OpenVPN server
  4. The container has internet access, my computer doesn't
  5. I can ping my computer from the container and I can ping the container from my computer, but there is no internet on my computer.

What am I missing? Can someone help please?

OR is there a way to stimulate a click on headset's/bluetooth's call answering button?

Any help would be appreciated!

items.body_markdown:
Since we are studying workloads in a distributed data-stored system over a certain period of time, what we need is patterns of user access to web servers in a decentralized hosting environment (as shown in the following figure - [server log][1]access log in server sites). One trace record we require needs to contain at least four features - timestamp (like MM:DD:SS), web server id, access file id (such as a tweet), and operations (e.g., create, read, or update a tweet). In other words, the access patterns need to include real hits on their servers during a certain period of time. 
Does anyone know whether it is possible to crawl or download similar sorts of user access datasets? Thank you.


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/mAAaR.jpg
items.title: Available user access traces to web-servers in a decentralized hosting environment
items.body: Since we are studying workloads in a distributed data-stored system over a certain period of time, what we need is patterns of user access to web servers in a decentralized hosting environment (as shown in the following figure - server logaccess log in server sites). One trace record we require needs to contain at least four features - timestamp (like MM:DD:SS), web server id, access file id (such as a tweet), and operations (e.g., create, read, or update a tweet). In other words, the access patterns need to include real hits on their servers during a certain period of time. Does anyone know whether it is possible to crawl or download similar sorts of user access datasets? Thank you.

items.body_markdown:
I have financial API for an app that keeps a user's balances of many different currencies. There is a ledger table of all transactions. Whenever I need to know a user's balance of a single currency or the whole portfolio I need to query the database. This is my query of the ledger to get a balance:

    def self.balance(user, account, currency)
      debit = where("user_id = ? AND account = ? AND currency = ?", user, account, currency).sum('debit')
      credit = where("user_id = ? AND account = ? AND currency= ?", user, account, currency).sum('credit')
      debit - credit
    end

The app provides a tonne of stats to a user, like profits/losses, portfolio percentages, etc. As a result, some of the end points take ~50 seconds to return the data, and `balances` method is being run dozens of times. The code is really modular because many of the methods are used repeatedly over many different end points.

I've tried adding indexes, but it hasn't sped up the end point return at all. 

I am not sure if there is way to cache this query during an API endpoint call, or if it's better to just make a `balances` table in the database instead of having to calculate it each time.
items.title: How do I speed up a Rails API route that has too many Active Record queries?
items.body:
I have financial API for an app that keeps a user's balances of many different currencies. There is a ledger table of all transactions. Whenever I need to know a user's balance of a single currency or the whole portfolio I need to query the database. This is my query of the ledger to get a balance:

def self.balance(user, account, currency)
  debit = where("user_id = ? AND account = ? AND currency = ?", user, account, currency).sum('debit')
  credit = where("user_id = ? AND account = ? AND currency= ?", user, account, currency).sum('credit')
  debit - credit
end

The app provides a tonne of stats to a user, like profits/losses, portfolio percentages, etc. As a result, some of the end points take ~50 seconds to return the data, and balances method is being run dozens of times. The code is really modular because many of the methods are used repeatedly over many different end points.

I've tried adding indexes, but it hasn't sped up the end point return at all.

I am not sure if there is way to cache this query during an API endpoint call, or if it's better to just make a balances table in the database instead of having to calculate it each time.

items.body_markdown:
This question is relevant to MySQL databases or tables that exceed 1 million rows. 

As each row shall have a unique ID (or code) which is later used to create relationships between several tables, is it more efficient to use a double integer ID such as "**1456156148489418189**" instead of string code such as "**ds156b1dsb4ds8b4sd6b14s864ea**".

Does for example JOIN or even SELECT have an easier time searching for a double integer than for a string in a table of more than million rows? If so is there some correlation such as 40 digit double integer is 50% more efficient as a UID than using 20 character string?
items.title: Are double integers more efficient as database IDs than string codes?
items.body:
This question is relevant to MySQL databases or tables that exceed 1 million rows.

As each row shall have a unique ID (or code) which is later used to create relationships between several tables, is it more efficient to use a double integer ID such as "1456156148489418189" instead of string code such as "ds156b1dsb4ds8b4sd6b14s864ea".

Does for example JOIN or even SELECT have an easier time searching for a double integer than for a string in a table of more than million rows? If so is there some correlation such as 40 digit double integer is 50% more efficient as a UID than using 20 character string?

items.title: Writing an alarm clock wanting it to change colors when active instead it only change once with errors
items.body:
Writing an alarm clock wanting it to change colors when active instead it only change once with errors saying :

Uncaught ReferenceError: ho is not defined at :1:1"

 function load() {                                  //global function
      var hVar,mVar;                                   //alarm set variables
      var timer = document.getElementById('timer');    //div with id of timer
      var audio = document.getElementById('audio');    //alarm sound

//my time reference//
      var myDate = new Date();
      Hours   = myDate.getHours();
      Minutes = myDate.getMinutes();
      Seconds = myDate.getSeconds();
      milliSeconds = myDate.getMilliseconds();

// alarms reformating function   
      var Hours = Hours < 10 ? '0'+ Hours : Hours;
      var Minutes = Minutes < 10 ? '0'+ Minutes : Minutes;
      var Seconds = Seconds < 10 ? '0'+ Seconds : Seconds;
      var milliSeconds = milliSeconds < 10 ? '0'+ milliSeconds : milliSeconds;

// string formation output //    
      timer.innerHTML =Hours +':'+ Minutes +':'+ Seconds+':'+milliSeconds;

         var hVar = document.getElementById('inputHours').value;   //alarm hours set
         var mVar = document.getElementById('inputMinutes').value; //alarm minutes set

           var  i=0;                                           //array index variable
           var myColor=['red','blue','green','black','white']; //color array
      function ho(){
           document.body.style.backgroundColor = myColor[i];   //array to dom
           i++;
           while(myColor[i]==myColor.lenght){                  //loop reset
              i=0;
           }
        } 
// if condition for alarm to be active //   
      if (Hours==hVar&&Minutes==mVar){
        audio.play();                               // alarminvokation
        setInterval('ho()','5000');                 //color change invocation
      }
      else {
              audio.pause();
      }
    setInterval('load()','100');
    }
    load();

items.body_markdown:
There may not be an elegant solution to this, but I'm hoping. I have a large array of observed vs predicted data (for several parameters) that I want to scatter plot. So far so good.

However, since the range of obs and pred data rarely matches, neither do the automatic axis limits. Is there a way to ask matlab to use the same axis limits for X & Y? "axis equal" doesn't quite do it - it seems to fix the aspect ratio, but not the limits.

While we're at it, it would be nice if it used the same ticking on both axes...
items.title: matlab figure with equal axes
items.body:
There may not be an elegant solution to this, but I'm hoping. I have a large array of observed vs predicted data (for several parameters) that I want to scatter plot. So far so good.

However, since the range of obs and pred data rarely matches, neither do the automatic axis limits. Is there a way to ask matlab to use the same axis limits for X & Y? "axis equal" doesn't quite do it - it seems to fix the aspect ratio, but not the limits.

While we're at it, it would be nice if it used the same ticking on both axes...

items.body_markdown:
In my program I have created a Geometry from the vertices of an intersection between a plane and a mesh. I use this Geometry to create a LineSegments object and it works perfectly. I would like to use the vertices in a couple of other ways as well, but the array of vertices in the Geometry is not in the correct order (the order that LineSegments draws them). I am unable to find where the information is stored that allows LineSegments to draw lines between the vertices in the correct order. The link below shows the problem:

https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/99353/vertex-ordering-with-threejss-exporter

There is only one answer that suggests that you check the faces for more information, but from what I can see there is no information about the faces in my Geometry, it only contains the vertices that I put in there. 

Any help would be much appreciated!
items.title: Order of vertices in Geometry
items.body:
In my program I have created a Geometry from the vertices of an intersection between a plane and a mesh. I use this Geometry to create a LineSegments object and it works perfectly. I would like to use the vertices in a couple of other ways as well, but the array of vertices in the Geometry is not in the correct order (the order that LineSegments draws them). I am unable to find where the information is stored that allows LineSegments to draw lines between the vertices in the correct order. The link below shows the problem:

https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/99353/vertex-ordering-with-threejss-exporter

There is only one answer that suggests that you check the faces for more information, but from what I can see there is no information about the faces in my Geometry, it only contains the vertices that I put in there.

Any help would be much appreciated!

items.title: Angular Firebase ngFor returning [object object]
items.body:
Database

"testTree" : {
"-L7SdD-wGoFfewfde2oI" : { //Firebase key
  "testX" : {
    "ef43E2Vde" : { // User Generated
      "testY" : {
        "numX" : 87,
      }
    },
    "Me5Eq2V9e" : { // User Generated
      "testY" : {
        "numX": 12
      }
    }
  },
  "treeName" : "TestTREE",
},
"-L7heD-VdO9efgDaIOp" : {
  "testX" : {
    "9vEf029QP" : {
      "testY" : {
        "numX" : 35,
      }
    }
  }
},

Function:

treeData: any[] = [];

getTree() {
this.db.list('/testTree/')
.valueChanges()
.subscribe(res => {
    Object.keys(res)
    .map(key => {
      this.treeData.push(res[key]);
      console.log(res[key]);
    })
})

}

HTML: 

<div *ngFor='let userData of treeData'>
{{ userData.devices }} //typo
{{ userData.testX }}

Output:

[object Object]
[object Object]  
[object Object]
[object Object]
[object Object]

From my understand *ngFor will only iterate over array but not object. I thought that I am storing and pushing the result to my array treeData. I just want to be able to output all 'numX'. What am I doing wrong? Will it even be possible to iterate my database with the "User Generated" to reach 'numX'?
